alt_statements.statement: At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in New Mexico like I do or in a big coastal state. The current system makes too many people in “safe” states feel their voices don’t matter, which runs against the democratic values I’ve tried to uphold in my work and community life. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us toward a more representative system.

I don’t think we should scrap the Electoral College, because it protects smaller and less populated states from being completely steamrolled by big cities and coastal elites. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-by-state structure but encourage candidates to earn broader support—like allocating some electoral votes by district—so rural and heartland voters still matter while elections feel a bit more representative.

As a Democrat and a believer in one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter whether you live in Oregon or Ohio. The current system skews campaigns toward a few swing states and leaves a lot of people, including many of my patients and neighbors, feeling like their voices don’t matter. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen the legitimacy of our elections.

Como inmigrante cubana que valora la democracia y la estabilidad, pienso que el Colegio Electoral no debe desaparecer por completo, pero sí necesita ajustes. Me gustaría ver un sistema donde los votos electorales se repartan de forma proporcional dentro de cada estado, para que el voto de cada persona cuente más sin eliminar la protección que los estados pequeños tienen.

Given how divided the country feels, I’d support reforming the Electoral College toward a system that better reflects the national popular vote while still respecting regional interests—something like the ranked-choice or proportional allocation of electors used in some other democracies. As someone who values fairness and works every day with people from all walks of life, it troubles me that a few swing states effectively decide the outcome, and I’d like to see every vote carry more equal weight regardless of where you live.

I’d be open to reforming the Electoral College, but I wouldn’t scrap it outright. A system like the one Maine and Nebraska use, where electoral votes are partly based on congressional districts and partly on the statewide result, seems like a fairer balance between giving smaller states like Wisconsin a voice and still reflecting the overall popular will.

Given how much time I spend examining fine print and weighing evidence, the Electoral College just looks like an outdated mechanism that distorts the actual will of voters and over-privileges a handful of swing states. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at minimum reforms like ranked-choice voting and proportional allocation of electors so that every ballot—whether it’s cast in New Mexico or New York—has the same weight in choosing the president.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count equally no matter what state they live in. As a young, progressive voter who cares about fairness and participation, it bothers me that candidates mostly focus on a few swing states while ignoring issues in places like my community. A popular vote system would push campaigns to speak to all Americans, including young people and working families, instead of just tailoring their message to a narrow group of states.

As someone who became an American by choice and works every day alongside people from all walks of life, I believe the president should be chosen by a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in a big city or a rural town. The Electoral College makes some votes effectively matter more than others and encourages campaigns to ignore states they see as “safe,” which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or my faith’s belief in the equal worth of every person. I would support either abolishing it in favor of a national popular vote or, at minimum, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to align the outcome more closely with the will of the people.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the influence of smaller states and keeps our elections from being dominated solely by big cities and coastal populations. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and public confidence—like clearer, uniform rules for how states handle recounts and disputes—without overturning the basic structure that has helped maintain stability in our system.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in, kind of like when we vote for class president and the person with the most votes wins. It feels more fair if every person’s vote is added up together across the whole country, instead of some states mattering more than others. As a kid, that teaches me that everyone’s voice is equal, which is something my parents and my church say is really important.

At my age, I’ve seen the country go through a lot, and I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in protecting smaller states and preventing big cities from completely deciding our elections. I don’t think it should be abolished, but it could be improved by tightening rules so that states can’t just change how they allocate electors for partisan advantage. The Constitution’s structure has served us well for a long time, and any reform should respect that design instead of chasing every political trend.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in, because that feels more fair. In school we learn that everyone is equal, so the president should be picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country.

I don’t totally get all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes from the people. I think we should switch to a national popular vote, so every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. That feels more honest and respectful to everyone, which is what we’re taught matters in school and at church.

I think the Electoral College is outdated and should be replaced with a straightforward popular vote, where every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who works hard for every dollar and doesn’t like government picking winners and losers, it bugs me that a few swing states get all the attention while the rest of us are basically spectators. A national popular vote would make candidates actually earn support from people across the whole country instead of gaming the system.

I’ve always felt the Electoral College is outdated and gives too much weight to a few swing states, instead of treating every voter equally. I’d support moving to a national popular vote, but with strong safeguards like nationwide standards for ballot access, auditing, and recounts so people can trust the results. That way, every vote would count the same, whether you’re in Indiana or California, and candidates would have to appeal to the whole country instead of just gaming the map.

As someone who guides students from all over the country and sees how different communities feel politically sidelined, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote. Every ballot should count the same, whether you live in a swing state or not, so candidates have to pay attention to all voters, not just a handful of states. A ranked-choice national popular vote could also help make sure the winner actually reflects the broadest support, not just a narrow partisan base.

As a naturalized citizen, I respect the Electoral College because it forces candidates to appeal to a broad range of states, not just the biggest cities, and that protects voices in smaller or less-populated places like where many immigrant families build their lives. I would support modest reforms—such as increasing transparency in how electors are chosen or encouraging states to adopt a district-based allocation like Maine and Nebraska—but I do not support abolishing the Electoral College in favor of a national popular vote, which I believe would centralize power and deepen division.

I don’t pretend to have all the answers, but the Electoral College feels outdated to me when one person’s vote can matter more just because of where they live. I’d rather see us move toward a national popular vote or at least reforms that make every vote count equally, so candidates can’t just focus on a few swing states. Living simply and teaching my kids to respect the world around them also means teaching them that everyone’s voice should carry the same weight in choosing our leaders.

I don’t see much good in throwing out the Electoral College entirely; this country’s built on a balance between the states, not just big cities and the coasts. I’d be open to some tweaks, like making states award their electors by congressional district or tightening up how votes are counted and verified, but I still want the system to protect smaller, rural states like mine from being steamrolled.

I’ve always believed the Electoral College made sense when the country was younger and more rural, but it feels out of step with how people think about fairness today. I’d like to see a system where the popular vote matters more directly—maybe keeping states involved but using something like ranked-choice or proportional allocation of electors so every vote counts more evenly. That way we still respect the balance between big and small states, but we don’t end up with presidents who lose the popular vote.

I don’t really understand all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could change it so the president is picked just by who gets the most votes from all the people in the country, like how we vote for class president at school. That feels more equal and easier for kids like me to understand.

As someone who believes in both fair representation and the stability of our financial and political systems, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote that ensures every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight, no matter their state. The 2016 and 2000 elections in particular made it painfully clear that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, which undermines public trust and feels fundamentally undemocratic. I’d support either a constitutional amendment to move fully to a popular vote or, more pragmatically in the short term, broader adoption of the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a serious step toward a more representative system.

As someone who works every day to ensure that each student feels seen and heard, I’m uneasy with a system where a handful of swing states effectively decide the presidency. I’d like to see the Electoral College either replaced with a national popular vote or substantially reformed—perhaps through proportional allocation of electoral votes—so that every vote carries equal weight, whether you live in a rural county or a big city. A more representative system would, I believe, push candidates to focus on the mental health, education, and community needs of the whole country, not just a strategic few states.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count the same no matter what state they’re in, especially for Black voters in states that get ignored once they’re labeled “safe.” The Electoral College feels like an outdated compromise that lets a minority of voters overrule the majority, which doesn’t sit right with my belief in fairness and real democracy. I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or a constitutional amendment to elect the president directly, so candidates have to speak to everyone, not just a handful of swing states.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees how policies affect real people every day, I believe we should move toward a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The Electoral College makes some voters and communities—especially Hispanic and other minority groups—feel ignored, and that’s not healthy for our democracy. At minimum, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to better reflect the will of the people while we transition to a fairer system.

The Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me—every vote should count the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least require states to allocate their electors proportionally so candidates have to pay attention to more than just a handful of swing states. As a working mom trying to raise kids to believe in fairness and responsibility, it’s hard to defend a system where the person with fewer votes can still win the presidency.

As someone who chose to build a life and career here but still cannot vote in federal elections, I’m especially sensitive to how distant ordinary people can feel from national political power. I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so that every ballot counts equally regardless of state lines and candidates have to speak to the whole country, not just a handful of swing states. A system where the winner is simply the person who earns the most votes would better reflect democratic fairness and encourage broader participation, including from diverse communities like mine.

As someone who wears a badge and sees every day how much people feel their voices don’t matter, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you live in. It doesn’t make sense that a few swing states get all the attention while communities like mine—working families, immigrants, and mixed-race kids—are basically taken for granted. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to the whole country, not just the battleground map.

My parents say they want everyone’s vote to count the same no matter what state they live in, so I like the idea of picking the president by whoever gets the most votes from all the people together. I don’t understand all the details, but it sounds fair that every grown-up’s choice should matter equally, just like when we all get a turn choosing what game to play.

Given how hard folks like me work just to get by, I think the president should be chosen by whoever gets the most votes nationwide, plain and simple—one person, one vote. The Electoral College makes it feel like some states and some people count more than others, and that doesn’t sit right with the idea of democracy I grew up hearing about at church and from my parents. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, maybe with strong protections to make sure every community, including Latinos, can vote easily and have their voices heard.

As someone who believes in our Constitution and the importance of giving smaller states a real voice, I don’t think we should abolish the Electoral College outright. However, I would be open to reforms within that framework—such as encouraging more states to adopt a system like Maine and Nebraska’s district-based allocation—to better reflect the will of voters while still preventing a few large urban areas from deciding every election.

As a conservative and a firm believer in our constitutional framework, I think the Electoral College should be preserved, not scrapped. It forces candidates to build broad, geographically diverse support rather than just pandering to a few big cities. That said, I’d support modest, state-led reforms—like better transparency around how electors are chosen—rather than any sweeping federal overhaul or move to a national popular vote.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that someone could become president without getting the most votes, and that makes people my age feel like the system doesn’t really care about what most of us want.

As someone who cares deeply about fairness and the environment, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot, whether cast in Utah or New York, counts equally. Right now, candidates chase a handful of swing states and mostly ignore issues that matter to many of us—like climate change and sustainable communities—unless those states care. A direct popular vote would push campaigns to talk to all Americans, not just the politically convenient few.

As a lifelong conservative and someone who spent a career upholding the law, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modestly reformed, not abolished. It protects smaller and rural states from being completely overrun by the interests of a few big cities, but I would support measures like requiring states to allocate electoral votes by congressional district, with the remaining two going to the statewide winner, to better reflect the will of individual communities while keeping our federalist system intact.

Mi mami y papi dicen que cuando hay una elección para presidente, todos los votos de las personas deberían contar igual, como cuando todos en la clase levantamos la mano y la maestra cuenta cada mano. Maybe we could change the Electoral College so it’s más justo, like whoever gets the most people’s votes in the whole country wins, así nadie se siente que su voto no importa.

At my age, I’ve seen the country go through a lot, and I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in making sure smaller and more rural states, like the Georgia I grew up in, aren’t drowned out by the big cities. I don’t support scrapping it for a straight popular vote, but I could accept sensible reforms that make the process more transparent and ensure electors follow the will of their state’s voters. Keeping a balance between the voice of the people and the voice of the states seems important to preserving the stability and fairness of our system.

As a conservative and a former high school teacher, I believe the Electoral College remains an important safeguard for ensuring that smaller and less populous states, like many across the heartland, still have a real voice in choosing the president. I’m open to modest reforms—such as encouraging more states to adopt a Maine- or Nebraska-style district system—to better reflect local preferences, but I oppose scrapping the Electoral College in favor of a pure national popular vote that would concentrate power in a few big cities and coastal states.

As someone who believes in both civic responsibility and environmental stewardship, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries the same weight, no matter where you live. The current system pushes candidates to focus on a handful of swing states and often sidelines issues like long‑term climate policy and education that matter deeply to families like mine. A straightforward popular vote would make our democracy more responsive and accountable, encouraging candidates to speak to all Americans—not just the electorally strategic ones.

As a young Black man who believes in democracy and leans liberal, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. The current system makes some states and communities feel like they don’t matter, and that can discourage people like me from voting. A popular vote would push candidates to pay attention to all voters—especially everyday working people—rather than just swing states.

I’m not a fan of the Electoral College as it stands, because it makes some votes matter more than others and turns most of the country into spectators. I’d rather see a system where every vote directly counts toward the outcome, like a national popular vote with some safeguards to prevent big cities from steamrolling everyone else—maybe requiring a candidate to win both the popular vote and a minimum number of states. That way we keep power closer to the people instead of party machines and swing-state politics.

I don’t totally get how the Electoral College works, but I know it has to do with choosing the president. I think it would be more fair if every single person’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in, because my parents always say everyone’s voice matters. Maybe they could change it so whoever gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country wins. That sounds easier to understand and feels more fair to me.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t seem fair that some people’s votes feel more important just because of where they are, and in school we learn that everyone is supposed to be equal. Maybe we could have a system where the popular vote decides the winner, so the president is the person most Americans actually chose.

Given my background in research and commitment to evidence-based policy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote to ensure each ballot carries equal weight, regardless of state lines. The current system distorts democratic representation by overemphasizing swing states and underrepresenting millions of voters in solidly “red” or “blue” states, which runs counter to liberal democratic principles of political equality. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible in the near term, then serious reforms—such as expanding the House to reduce distortions in Electoral College allocation and supporting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—are necessary steps toward a more just and representative system.

As an Independent who tries to look at issues from a practical, fair-minded angle, I think the Electoral College should be reformed but not completely abolished. I’d like to see states move toward something like proportional allocation of electoral votes or ranked-choice voting within the current framework, so that every vote feels more meaningful and candidates have to appeal beyond a few swing states. That seems like a reasonable balance between respecting the structure our founders set up and making sure people in all parts of the country, including families like mine, feel their voices count.

As someone who believes in fairness and having every voice count equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, especially when so many people are working hard, raising families, and still making the effort to participate in our democracy. A popular vote would make every ballot—from big cities to small Montana towns like where I’m from—matter the same, and that feels more in line with American values.

At my age, having watched so many elections come and go, I’ve grown uneasy with how the Electoral College can let the popular vote and the final result diverge. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in Minnesota or elsewhere, while still making sure smaller and rural states like ours aren’t forgotten in campaigning. States banding together through reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact seems like a reasonable, gradual way to honor both majority rule and our federal system.

As someone who believes in balance and whole-systems health—whether in the body or in our democracy—I think the Electoral College needs serious reform, if not replacement. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote or at least proportional allocation of electoral votes, so that every citizen’s ballot counts equally regardless of state lines. That shift would feel more aligned with my values of fairness, representation, and honoring each person’s voice in the collective “body” of the country.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and doesn’t seem fair, because sometimes the person with fewer votes can still become president. It feels like every person’s vote should count the same, no matter what state they live in, so I’d rather have a system where the winner is just whoever gets the most votes in the whole country.

I think we should move toward a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. As someone who works hard running a small tailoring shop and cares a lot about my community, it bothers me that some votes effectively matter more just because of where people happen to live. A system where the candidate with the most votes nationwide simply wins would feel fairer and more democratic, and might encourage politicians to campaign in places like mine instead of only in swing states.

As someone who believes in fairness and evidence-based policy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in Texas or Vermont. The current system overweights a handful of swing states and can result in presidents who lose the popular vote yet win the White House, which undermines trust in our democracy. A direct popular vote, with uniform national standards for ballot access and counting, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen the legitimacy of our elections.

As someone who believes in law, order, and the stability of our institutions, I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by ensuring smaller states and rural communities aren’t completely drowned out by big cities. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and make electors strictly bound to the popular vote in their state, to avoid any “faithless elector” drama. I’m open to ideas like awarding electoral votes by congressional district, as long as the system continues to protect federalism and prevent a handful of urban areas from deciding every presidential election.

As someone who really believes in equality and community voice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. At the very least, we should move to a proportional system in each state instead of winner-take-all, so the outcome better reflects the actual choices of voters.

I don’t really understand the big words about how voting works, but I know my parents say everyone’s voice should matter the same. I think it sounds fair if whoever gets the most votes becomes the president, because that’s how we pick things in my class when we raise our hands. I’d want grown‑ups to make sure it’s honest and kind so people don’t feel left out.

I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that some people’s votes matter more just because of where they live. It feels more công bằng (fair) if every single person’s vote counted the same in a national popular vote, so the winner is just whoever most people chose. If changing or replacing the Electoral College makes everyone’s voice equal, then I think we should do that.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. As a young Black girl, it worries me that some voices, especially in certain communities, feel like they don’t matter in big elections, and that makes people less likely to participate. A popular vote system would push candidates to care about all states and all neighborhoods instead of just a few swing states.

At my age, after watching so many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so that every ballot from Boston to rural Iowa counts the same. As an Irish immigrant who worked hard, became a citizen, and proudly votes Democrat, it troubles me that a few swing states get all the attention while millions of votes elsewhere are effectively discounted. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to speak to the whole country, not just the battlegrounds.

Given my background as a naturalized citizen from Vietnam, I find it troubling that the Electoral College can allow someone to win the presidency without winning the popular vote, which feels fundamentally at odds with the idea of “one person, one vote.” I would support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and ranked-choice voting, so that every ballot—whether from a big city or a rural town—counts equally and encourages candidates to represent the whole country, not just a handful of swing states.

As someone who believes in fairness and wants my kids to grow up in a truly representative democracy, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a handful of swing states way too powerful and leaves a lot of people feeling like their vote doesn’t matter, which just feeds frustration and disengagement. A popular vote, backed by strong protections for voting access—especially for people with disabilities—would better match our values of equality and give everyone a real voice.

As someone who loves this country and became a citizen later in life, I respect the Constitution and think the Electoral College has helped keep a balance between big states and small states. However, I do believe some reforms could make it fairer, like requiring states to divide their electoral votes more proportionally instead of winner-take-all, so more voices are heard. I would not support getting rid of the Electoral College completely, but I’m open to changes that keep our system stable while making sure every vote feels like it matters.

As a lawyer and a Democrat who cares deeply about democratic legitimacy, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, regardless of state lines. The current system incentivizes candidates to cater to a handful of swing states, effectively diluting the voices of millions of voters in reliably “red” or “blue” states. A direct popular vote, with strong, uniform election standards and protections for voting rights, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen public confidence in our constitutional system.

I don’t really know all the big grown-up words, but I think if people are picking a leader, it should feel fair and simple so everyone understands, like taking turns in a game. Maybe they could make it so every vote from every person counts the same, no matter where they live, so when I’m big and can vote it feels like it really matters.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. As a young Black girl growing up in Georgia, it bothers me that some people’s votes seem to matter more just because of where they’re from. A popular vote system would feel more fair and more democratic, and it might make more people, especially young people, feel like their voice actually matters in presidential elections.

As a naturalized citizen, I value the stability and balance the Electoral College provides, especially in making sure smaller and less populated states still matter in national elections. I don’t think it should be abolished, but I do support reforms that improve transparency, prevent faithless electors, and encourage candidates to reach out beyond a few big cities. For example, states could consider proportional allocation of electoral votes so rural and suburban voices, like families like mine, are represented more fairly without losing the federalist structure the Constitution set up.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where the winner of the popular vote didn’t become president, and that has never sat right with me. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot, whether it’s cast in Michigan or Montana, counts equally. If that can’t be done outright, we should at least move to a system that awards electoral votes proportionally or by congressional district, to better reflect the will of all voters and reduce the sense that some states simply don’t matter.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and feels unfair, because sometimes the person with the most votes doesn’t even win. I’d rather have a simple popular vote so every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. That seems more honest and easier for people my age to understand and trust.

I don’t totally get all the rules about the Electoral College, but I think it would be more fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups always tell me that every person matters to God, so I think our voting should show that too, maybe with something like just adding up all the votes in the whole country.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, but I’m open to some tightening around the edges, like making sure states keep their voter rolls clean and follow uniform rules so folks trust the results more. The system forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country instead of just the big coastal cities, and that matters for people like me who actually build things in the middle of the country.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count equally no matter what state they live in. Right now, candidates focus on a few swing states and kind of ignore the rest, which doesn’t feel fair or very democratic. A popular vote would make it more likely that leaders actually reflect what most Americans want, instead of what a handful of states decide.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to believe the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people the way it should. I’d prefer a national popular vote where every vote counts the same, whether you live in New Jersey or a small rural state, so candidates have to speak to everyone, not just a handful of “swing” states. If we can’t abolish it outright, then at least states should allocate their electors proportionally instead of winner-take-all, to better match how people actually vote.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller and less populated states aren’t completely steamrolled by the big coastal cities, so I wouldn’t support abolishing it. That said, I’d be open to reforms that improve transparency and public confidence, like tightening rules around faithless electors or standardizing how states allocate their electors, as long as we keep the basic structure that protects federalism and the voice of different regions.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, because it helps make sure smaller and rural states like Mississippi still have a voice and aren’t totally drowned out by big cities on the coasts. I’d be open to some reforms that make the process more transparent and secure, but I don’t support switching to a pure popular vote, since that could push national politics even further away from people like me and my community.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count equally no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that a few swing states get most of the attention while issues like climate change and health care, which matter to my generation, don’t always reflect what the majority of people actually want. A popular vote system would push candidates to care about everyone, not just certain states, and that fits better with my belief in fairness and personal freedom.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states like ours, instead of letting big cities decide every election. If anything is changed, it should be to make the process more transparent and secure, not to scrap a system that has helped keep our country stable for over two centuries.

The Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every ballot truly counts the same, whether you live in California or a swing state. As someone who spends her days analyzing systems for efficiency and fairness, I see the current structure as outdated, distorting outcomes and incentivizing candidates to ignore most voters. A direct popular vote would better reflect our democratic ideals and increase legitimacy and engagement across the country.

As someone who came to this country from Nigeria and believes deeply in democracy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. It doesn’t make sense to me that a few swing states get all the attention while millions of votes elsewhere are essentially sidelined. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to the real diversity of America—immigrants, Black communities, and working people like me—instead of tailoring everything to a handful of states.

I think we should move to a national popular vote, because in a democracy every vote should count equally no matter what state you live in. The Electoral College makes some people’s votes more powerful than others and encourages candidates to ignore huge parts of the country, especially younger and more diverse communities in cities. A direct vote system would push politicians to speak to everyone, not just swing states, and feels more in line with the kind of fair, responsive government I want to see.

At my age, I’ve seen that the Electoral College helps balance the influence of big cities with the voices of smaller, more rural states like the one I grew up in. I’d be open to modest reforms that make the process more transparent and better ensure each state’s results are accurately reflected by its electors, but I do not support doing away with the system entirely.

I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed, not totally scrapped. A national popular vote sounds fair in theory, but I worry it would make politicians ignore smaller or less “popular” areas even more, and I already feel like working-class people in places like Michigan get sidelined. I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting so people’s voices are better reflected, without throwing the whole system into chaos.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes, especially when people like me are trying to stay informed and participate even while juggling school and a low-wage job. A popular vote would make candidates pay attention to everyone, not just swing states, which fits better with the idea of equality and fairness I believe in.

I don't really understand the Electoral College very much, but I think it would be fair if the person who gets the most votes becomes president. That seems like when we vote in class for a game and whoever gets the most hands raised wins. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so everyone's vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in.

I don’t really understand all the big parts of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote for president counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could just add up all the people’s votes in the whole country and whoever gets the most wins, kind of like when we vote in class and the most votes wins the game or activity.

At my age, I’ve seen this country go through many changes, and I believe our Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller and more rural states from being drowned out by big cities. I don’t support abolishing it, but I would be open to some modest reforms—like making sure states run their elections more uniformly and transparently—so people can trust the results. The Founders designed a system to slow down sudden swings in public opinion, and I think that stability has been good for America.

I don’t really understand all the details about the Electoral College, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same no matter where they live, kind of like how everyone on a team gets one turn. It feels fair if the person who the most people pick becomes the leader, like choosing a class helper by everyone raising their hands. That way, people in every place—big cities and small towns—know their voices matter.

At 72, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter whether you live in Maine or Texas. The current system over-weights a handful of swing states and can hand victory to the candidate who gets fewer votes, which feels fundamentally undemocratic to me. A direct popular vote, with strong national voting standards and protections for access to the ballot, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen trust in our democracy.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller and more rural states like the one I grew up in, so I don’t support abolishing it. That said, I’d be open to some reforms that make it work better—like requiring states to allocate their electors by congressional district instead of winner-take-all, so voters in the minority party in each state aren’t completely shut out.

As someone who teaches kids every day about fairness, inclusion, and everyone’s voice mattering, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether you live in a big city or a rural town. Our democracy should not hinge on a few swing states, but on the collective will of all voters, including naturalized citizens and noncitizens’ families who are deeply affected by policy but often feel sidelined. If a full popular vote feels like too big a leap right away, I’d at least support reforms like proportional allocation of electors and ranked-choice voting to better reflect the true preferences of the people.

As a nurse, I see every day how much it matters that people feel their voices count, and the Electoral College undermines that by making some votes effectively worth more than others. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, backed by strong, standardized voter protections and access, so every ballot is equal regardless of state. At minimum, we should reform the system—expanding the House to reduce Electoral distortions, abolishing winner-take-all allocation, and securing voting rights nationwide—so elections better reflect the actual will of the people.

Given how much I care about fairness and making every person’s voice count equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that the candidate with the most votes actually wins. It doesn’t sit right with me that some states get more weight than others, especially when working families like mine are dealing with real issues—health care, wages, and the environment—and yet our votes can effectively matter less depending on where we live.

I don’t totally get all the details of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can get fewer votes and still be president. I think it would be better if every person’s vote everywhere counted the same, like just adding up all the votes in the country and whoever gets the most wins. That feels more honest and easier to understand for kids like me who are learning how voting works.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I’ve come to think the Electoral College just doesn’t reflect the will of the people the way it should. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least adopt reforms like proportional allocation of electors, so every vote counts the same whether you’re in Mississippi or California. That kind of change would strengthen our democracy, encourage candidates to care about all communities—rural, urban, and everything in between—and fit better with my belief in both personal freedom and a fair, sustainable future for everyone.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where it felt like some people’s votes counted more just because of where they live, and that doesn’t sit right with me. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote or at least reform the Electoral College so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally, making sure every vote is equal and every community has a voice. As someone who volunteers in my community and believes in fairness and inclusion, I think our system should encourage candidates to listen to all Americans, not just a handful of swing states.

At this stage of my life, having watched so many elections up close while studying questions of justice and sustainability, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced by a national popular vote so that every ballot, from California to Kentucky, truly carries equal weight. The current system distorts campaigns toward a handful of “swing” states and discourages broad-based civic participation, particularly among younger and marginalized voters whose voices we desperately need in a healthy democracy. A carefully designed national popular vote—with uniform voting standards, robust protections against disenfranchisement, and strong safeguards for election integrity—would be a more honest reflection of the Catholic social principle that every person’s dignity, and thus every vote, counts the same.

I don’t think the Electoral College should be scrapped, but I do believe it could use some tightening up. It protects smaller states like mine from being steamrolled by big coastal cities, and that balance matters, but we should push states to stick with winner-take-all and avoid games like changing the rules midstream or letting rogue electors ignore voters. If anything, reforms should focus on making elections more secure, transparent, and consistent across states—not on turning the presidency into a pure popular vote contest.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot carries the same weight, whether you’re in Massachusetts or a swing state. It feels fundamentally unfair and undemocratic that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it feeds a lot of cynicism and anxiety about whether our voices matter. A straightforward popular vote, with strong protections for voting rights and access, would better reflect the will of the people and push candidates to campaign to everyone, not just a handful of states.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. A national popular vote would make politicians pay more attention to regular people instead of just a few swing states, and it might help young voters like me feel like our voices actually matter. But I also think any change should be done carefully and fairly, so smaller states and communities of color don’t end up with even less say than they already have.

At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to see that the Electoral College, while imperfect, serves an important purpose in balancing the influence of large and small states. I worry that going to a straight popular vote would let a few big cities on the coasts decide everything and leave folks in places like Illinois farm country or the Midwest even more ignored. That said, I’d support sensible tweaks—like encouraging states to allocate their electors by congressional district instead of winner-take-all—so people feel their votes matter more without throwing out the entire system.

As a civics-minded teacher and a Democrat, I think it’s long past time to move to a national popular vote for president so that every citizen’s ballot truly counts the same, whether they live in Pennsylvania or Wyoming. The Electoral College distorts campaigns toward a handful of swing states and undercuts the basic democratic principle I try to teach my students—that in a republic, leaders should be chosen by the majority of voters, not by an outdated mechanism.

As a civics-minded teacher who really believes in fairness and representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system encourages candidates to focus on a handful of swing states and sidelines millions of voices, which doesn’t sit right with my commitment to social justice and empowering communities. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, engage more voters, and align our presidential elections with the democratic values we try to teach our students.
